Oaths of Allegiance - 1777 Pittsylvania County, VA copy done by Cynthia Hu bbard Headen

source: The Magazine of VA Genealogy, v.23, #1 (Feb.1985), transcr ibed by Marian Dodson Chiarito

These lists were taken from a typewritten copy found in the Clerk's Of fice, Pittsylvania County, at Chatham, Virginia. The two following affida vits found attached to the copy are self- explanatory.

I, S. H. F. Jones, do hereby certify that about the year 1930 I persona lly copied and had checked the names of persons who took the oath of Alleg iance in 1777 as shown by manuscripts then in the Clerk's Office of Pittsy lvania County, Virginia. The writing was faded and a few names could n ot be deciphered. Every effort was made to transcribe the names as they a ppeared on the manuscripts. The names of the foregoing Lists are a true a nd correct copy of the aforesaid manuscripts to the best of my knowledge a nd belief. The lists were also checked by Mr. Langhorne Jones, att

Given under my hand and seal this 8th day of November, 193 9. S. H. F. Jones (Seal)

John Nuckles

In Pittsylvania County, Virginia Deeds 1778-1780

Page 455 March 21, 1780 from John Nuckles and Ann his wife of CP a nd P to Nathaniel Murrey (Murray) of CP and P, for 100 frances a tra ct of about 200 acres on the south side of the Double Creeks, joining t he lower end of Sarah Dupea's which sd tract of land was bequeathed to t he sd John Nuckles's wife Ann Nuckles by her father, Thomas Hardey in h is will Signed John (X his mark) Nuckles, Ann (X her mark) Nuckles,.Wit no ne. Sd Ann Nuckles relinquished her right of dower tothe lands within men tioned. Recorded Mar 21 1780

Page 477, March 21, 1780 John Nuckles and Ann, his wife of CP and P, to Ch arles Wright of the Parish of Littleton and County of Cumberland, for 6 00 frances, about 100 acres on Cherry Stone Cr in P, and bounded by Thom as Hardey, the Order Line. Signed John (X his mark) Nuckles, Ann (X her m ark) Nuckles. Wit-none. Recorded Mar 21 1780

Page 49 Deed of Gift July 27, 1774 from John Weatherford of P, to David W eatherford of P, for the natural love he has for his son David Weatherfor d, and for the further consideration of 5 shillings, one certain tra ct of land in P on Cherrystone Cr [this is lined through] containing abo ut 200 acres, bounded by the lines [this is lined through] of Thomas Hard y, David Wade, John Nuchkols, and the said John Weatherford. Signed Jno W eatherford. Wit - none. Recorded July 28, 1774

Three of my direct ancestors signed one of the many petitions:David "Dav e" Shrader, Sr., (name entered as D. Screder in 1796-1797 and as David Sh reder in 1799) , Frederick Sluer (should be Sluss-Americanized from Schlos ser - Frederick also known as Jared Sluss. His name was entered as Frederi ck Sluss on the 1797 & 1798 petition) and John Knuckles, Jr. (This name Am ericanized to Nuckles).

[DI11910] Died of Congenital Heart Disease; I was told she was a blue baby.

[DI11913] FRANCISCO, Theodore Waddy, 84, of Richmond, widower of Donna Langner Francisco, his wife of 62 years, died Wednesday, March 21, 2012. He was a son of the late Maurice G. and Latine Nuckolls Francisco. He is survived by five children, Michael W. Francisco and his wife, Maxine, Peter L. Francisco and his wife, Sharon, Jon G. Francisco and his wife, Susana, Brooke F. "Bonnie" Turner and Jeffrey W. Francisco and his wife, Carole; seven grandchildren, Patti Hornstra, Susana May Jordan, Jon Francisco, Benjamin Francisco, Clifton Turner, Jacob Turner and Amanda Francisco; five great-grandchildren; and five sisters, Alice Scott, Edith Buckley, Mary Jane Sale, Martha Francisco-Beck and Rebecca Duke. Mr. Francisco was preceded in death by two brothers, Maurice Francisco Jr. and Charles Francisco. He grew up in Beaverdam and was a graduate of Beaverdam High School. Mr. Francisco served in the U.S. Navy Seabees during World War II. He founded and owned Lakeside Appliance for 50 years. Mr. Francisco was a member of Emmanuel Episcopal Church, Brook Hill, for more than 60 years, where he served on the Vestry and in various other capacities. He loved boating, fishing and his home on the Rappahannock River. The family will receive friends from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m. Friday at the Central Chapel of Bennett Funeral Home, 3215 Cutshaw Avenue. Funeral services will be held 4 p.m. Saturday, March 24, at Emmanuel Episcopal Church. Burial will follow in the church cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Emmanuel Episcopal Church, 1214 Wilmer Ave., Richmond, Va. 23227.

Published in Richmond Times-Dispatch from March 22 to March 23, 2012

[DI11914] Husband of Mary Joseph Francisco.

Obituary published in "The Central Virginian" on October 29, 2004.

"Charles Peter Francisco, 75, of Beaverdam, died Wednesday, October 20, 2004. A Mass of the Resurrection was held at 11 a.m. Saturday. October 23 at Immaculate Conception Catholic Church, Buckner. Interment was in the church cemetery. He is survived by his wife, Mary Joseph Francisco; four sons, Charles P. Francisco Jr. of Richmond, G. Rhett Francisco and his wife, Sue, of Cincinnati, Ohio, John Cary Francisco and his wife, Janet, of Princeton, New Jersey, and Richard G. Francisco of Beaverdam; two daughters, Sandra J. Francisco and her husbnd, Wayne Skinner, and Theresa T.F. Goff and her husband, David, all of Richmond; two brothers, Maurice Francisco Jr. of Nashville, Tennessee, and T. Waddy Francisco of Richmond; five sisters, Alice Scott of Louisville, Kentucky, Edith Buckley of Annadale, Mary Jane Sale of Richmond, Martha Beck of Mechanicsville and Becky Duke of Mineral; and eight grandchildren.

He was a member of the American Legion Post 90, Beaverdam Ruritan and was Third Degree in the Knights of Columbus.

Memorial contributions may be made to a favorite charity, the Parkinson Disease Foundation or Immaculate Conception Catholic Church Building Fund, P.O. Box 40, Mineral, VA 23117."

[DI11918] NUCKOLS, Lucille Whitten, 97, of Richmond, passed away on January 5, 2012. She was the daughter of the late Marvin and Pearl Whitten, born on October 17, 1914. Lucille retired from Miller & Rhoads and was a longtime member of Mt. Vernon Baptist Church. Lucille was preceded in death by her beloved husband of over 60 years, Nathaniel Nuckols. She is survived by two daughters, Nancy Eanes of Danville, Va., and Jane Thurston of Richmond; two sisters, Audrey Ogdes of Roanoke Rapids, N.C., and Ethel Kingsburg of North Carolina. She had six grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. The family will receive friends at 10 a.m. on Monday, followed by a funeral service at 11 a.m. at the Woody Funeral Home, 1771 N. Parham Rd., Richmond, Va. Interment will follow at Greenwood Memorial Gardens

[NI11977] Parentage not proven. There is a preponderance of the evidence. This Abner fits the birth location. We know that the Civil War record with the ini tial of "T" is not necessarily accurate. I see many J's transcribed as a " T". Also since Jackson named a son Martin, this Abner had a brother named Martin which fits with family naming patterns. Son Martin naming a son Nathaniel confirms the identity with further evidence His military pension records clearly name him as Abner T Nuckols and military records match place of birth and living in Magoffin County KY most of his life. Only variant is in all census records his name is Jackson or Jack..

Distressing Casualty - A correspondent of the Richmond Dispatch states th at on Thursday, the 23rd inst, the dwelling house of Miss nancy Nuckols, in the neighborhood of Rockville, in the upper end of Hanover County, w as burned down about 11 o'clock A.M. At the time of the fire there w as no one in the house except Elizabeth Nuckols, her sister, an invalid so uttewrly helpless as to be able to get up when down. She was burn ed up near the door, having crawled , it is supposed, thus far, as her bones were found in that position. The family were in very needy circumstances, and the fire has utterly distroyed all their earthly possessions in t he shape of food and clothing.

[NI12078] My impression has been that the traditional claim was not that Thomas Huckaby married Keziah YANCEY, but that he married Keziah NUCKOLLS? Correct me if I am wrong. Of course, Keziah, wife of Charles Nuckolls, was a Yancey by birth. Nothing about the traditional claim ever seemed to quite fit including the projected birth date for Charles Nuckolls' daughter Keziah which was a little too late to for her to be Thomas Huckaby 's wife and the mother of his first child. However, the proof that Charles Nuckoll's daughter, Keziah, was not Thomas Huckaby's wife is on Dennis Yancey's site for Richard Yancey probate records which clearly lists the heirs of Charles and Keziah (Yancey) Nuckolls and shows that their daughter, Keziah, was a spinster and still unmarried in 1810 when a major suit involving the estate took place.

I think it very likely that Thomas Huckaby married Kezekiah/Keziah Self, daughter of William Self of Cumberland Co., Va. Thomas Huckaby was living there about the time of the marriage, Kezekiah/Keziah Self was the correct age, and William Self's will proved in 1791 shows that his daughter was married to a Huckaby. I know of no other Huckaby in Cumberland County at the correct time to marry William Self's daughter, nor do I know of any other Huckaby of that general era with a wife named Keziah/Kezeiah. William Self had ties to both Cumberland and Bedford counties, both associated with the Huckabys. Also, William Self sold his Campbell Co land (formerly in Bedford) to Joseph Chaffin, a near kinsman of Thomas Huckabys.

If you have any evidence contradicting any of my assertions, please let me know. I was once told that a granddaughter of Thomas Huckaby had the name, Keziah Nuckolls Huckaby. If proven, that would be significant, but I have not been able to find the evidence.

FAMILYOF ROBERT KNUCKLES AND MARGARET HENDRICKSON (CALLED PEGGY) AS

TOLD BY GREAT GRANDSONS COLSON KNUCKES AND FRANKLIN KNUCKLES

Much of the following genealogy are true statements related to the writers by Robin Nuckols (Colson's grandpa) and other kinfolk. Franklin Knuckles is a son of Millard Knuckles and Lydia Greene, and has been a great help to me in this endeavor .

Robert Knuckles or Nuckols was 45 years old in the 1860 Census. He was born 1815 -died 1905 (at age 90) and is buried at the Stoney Fork Cemetery near where Stoney Fork empties into the Right Fork of Straight Creek. He gave his place of birth in Virginia. (He was the son of Obadiah Knuckoles or Nuckols (Virginia records spelled his name Obediah Nuchols) and his mother was Elizabeth Willis who were married Feb. 3, 1801 in Goochland, V A.) Robert had one brother William Knuckles or Nuckols. When the brothers came into Kentucky , Robert made his home in the mountains. William went on down in the flat lands of Kentucky .My grandpa told me they never saw each other again. Prior to their arrival in Kentucky the family name was most often spelled NUCKELS or NUCKOLLS; in Kentucky however, KNUCKLES has been used most often. Other spellings of this name, as found in old records in the Virginias, and in the Carolinas were: NUCKOLS, NICHOLS, NICKOLS, KNUCKEL, NICOLS. NICHOLLS.

Robert Knuckles made his home at Knuckles Branch in Stoney Fork of Bell County He went down to Lone Jack, Four Mile, Ky. , and courted and married Margaret Hendrickson (born J anuary 1, 1820 in Knox Cty ., K y .-died March 14, 1890 (lived 70 years) , buried at Stoney Fork, Bell Cty. Ky. She was a daughter of Reuben Hendrickson and Hannah Davis (Reuben's parents were Ezekiel & Jemima (Mima) Hendrickson, who came to Kentucky ca. 1808. I believe Ezekiel's daddy was from Norway, and his mother was German -I do not know her name). Margaret Hendrickson was 39 years old in the 1860 Census and gave her place of birth in Kentucky .Margaret's brothers and sisters were:(a) William (who married fIrst Deborah Bingham; second Margaret S usher.(b) Rachel (who married Michael Howard, son of John Howard).(c) Nancy (who married Jacob Perciful). (d) Sally (who married Samuel Lock( e) on July 26, 1848). (e) Joel (who married fIrst Nancy Bullard; second Eliza Bullard). (t) Noah (who married Diadame Bingham). (g) George (who married Elizabeth Christine Steele). (h) Mary (who married John Amis). (i) John (who married Frances Tinsley). (j) Martha Jane (who married John Epperson). In the summer of 1993 regrading and widening of the Highway at Four Mile forced the relocation of the graves of Margaret's parents, Reuben and Hannah, her brothers George and John and their families. They all were reburied in Pinelawn a beautiful, perpetual care cemetery just east of Pineville, which was developed by Earl J. Knuckles (ninth child of James F. Knuckles & Lily Napier. )

Two Memories I have of greeat-gran daddy, called Old Man Bobby Knuckles by Colson Knuckles ©

He was at the voting place at Stoney Fork and a group of men were giving young George Knuckles a hard time because George was working for a man they did not want elected. Old man Bobby Knuckles went to these men and told them, "You fellows lay off that Colt and try an old horse a while." ©

Young George said they never bothered him again.

At another time a man by the name of Baker was running against Jack Forester. Old man Bobby was voting for Jack. Some man working and making a speach for Baker said "A Jack is no good without a Jenny". Bobby Knuckles said "Dam a Baker without a kid." ©

Filed a CW Pension application for both sons Reuben and George 11/21/1887 as surviving father

[DI12119] Randall Knuckles 4/2016

Found some interesting records today. First, I can find no will or affidavit for Robert. I went all the way back to Will Book 1 and even flipped through those recorded within the timeframe of what we know has to be his death. Nothing even close in K's or N's. So it seems we're still stuck with a three year period from 1893-1896. He bought property in 1893 which suggests he wasn't expecting to die anytime soon. I'd take a guess at 1895 since heirs are usually quick to cash in. That might be as close as we get.

REMEMBERANCES OF GREAT-GREAT AUNT SALLY AND GREAT-GREAT UNCLE BILL NUCKO LS as told to Colson Knuckles

Morgan Helton (son of Carlo Helton) told me "Uncle" Bill Nuckols' Dad w as Arnold Helton. "Uncle" Bill Nuckols had the fIrst store and the first p ost office on Red Bird, in the headwaters of Red Bird. His greatgrandson w as Grover Knuckles (born April 7, 1923 -died January 7, 1994), who liv ed in Blanchester, Ohio. I never saw Grover Knuckles, but he wrote to me a nd told me "Uncle" Bill Nuckols first called the new post office Red Bir d, Kentucky. Later "Uncle" Bill Nuckols changed the post office name to Be verly, Kentucky.

"Uncle" Bill Nuckols was a Veteran of the Civil War, a Union Soldier. He c ame back from the war and courted and married Amanda Jane Asher (a daught er of Wilkerson Asher and Lucinda Bingham). I believe "Uncle" Bill Nucko ls (the stepson of Obadiah Nuckols) changed the spelling of the name "Nuck ols" to "Knuckles"-

"Uncle" Bill Nuckols and his wife Amanda Jane Asher had the following chil dren: (I) George Matt Knuckles; (2) Letcher Knuckles; (3) Millard Knuckle s; (4) Tom Knuckles; and (5) John Beverly Knuckles.

Tom Knuckles was the grandpa of Grover Knuckles. I don't know which was na med fIrst, the the Beverly, Ky. post office or "Uncle" Bill Nuckols' son J ohn Beverly Knuckles. (If I knew the age of the Beverly post office, I wou ld know which was first, as I some times see John Beverly Knuckles tomb st one) .

From History of Bell Co by Henry Fuson Vol I

CHAPTER VII EARLY SETTLERS OF BELL COUNTY, CONTINUED

A. THE TWO STRAIGHT CREEKS AND RED BIRD I. RED BIRD SECTION

There were three main families on Red Bird when I knew the peop le in this part of the county. They were Bill Knuckles, Rev. Wilkerson Ash er, and Benjamin D. Bingham. These families and their ancestors and descen dants will follow in order. Bill Knuckles married a daughter of Re v. Wilkerson Asher, by name of Amanda Jane Asher. They had six children: ( 1) George M. Knuckles, (2) James Knuckles, (3) T. J. Knuckles, (4) J. B. K nuckles, (5) W. L. Knuckles, (6) M. F. Knuckles.

History of Bell Co, KY by Henry Fuson Vol II

Some of the more progressive families tried to stem the tide of lawlessne ss and to bring about a better condition. They keenly felt the need of bet ter schools for the training of their children. Among these families was t he Knuckles family. When they learned that the Evangelical Church was desi rous of establishing work in some section of the southern mountains, th ey contacted the leaders of the church and invited them to send representa tives to visit this region. When they arrived the Knuckles brothers gave t hem a hearty welcome and offered them the choice of their land upon whi ch to build their buildings and establish a school. These representative a ccepted the offer and steps were taken to begin operations.

William Richard Knuckles was one of five children born to Carolina Elza da Howard Knuckles, daughter of John R and Mary Alabama Howard and Willi am Letcher Knuckles of Beverly, formerly Knuckles, KY. William Letcher Knu ckles was one of five brothers. The other brothers were Millard Fillmore K nuckles, George Matt Knuckles, John Beverly Knuckles and Thomas Jeffers on Knuckles, all sons of William Richard Knuckles (himself) a son of Willi am Richard Knuckles and Mary Robinson Knuckles, a circuit-riding lawyer/ju dge. Wife of (the middle) William R Knuckles and mother of five sons was A manda Jane Asher Knuckles, daughter of Wilkerson Asher and Lucinda Bingh am Asher, a storekeeper and direct descendant of Dillion Asher, who settl ed near what is now Queendale, KY, near Beverly and Red Bird. The brothe rs donated five acres, more or less, of valley and surrounding mountainsi de land for the construction of the Red Bird settlement School and the Bev erly Evangelical United Brethren Church(now Beverly United Methodist Churc h) Afyer graduating from Red Bird High School in the second graduating cla ss, Bill, as he was known to his family and friends, attended and graduat ed from Union College, after which he taught school for 13 years in Bell C ounty, KY. He then graduated from the Univeristy of Kentucky College of La w, after which, even at a late age, he volunteered for wervice in the Unit ed States Marine Corps, from which he was honorably discharged as a seco nd lieutenant at the cose of WWII. He served in classification of milita ry personnel stateside. Soon after establising a law practice, firs tin pa rtnership with W J Stone and then Lester Parrott and finally establishi ng his own law practice, he married Marjorie Juanita Chambers, daught er of Rev M L and Dona Moore Chambers, a native of Williamsburg, who was s erving the Bell County School System, along with Warren Robbins, as helpi ng teacher (now called Supervisor of Schools) Marjorie had taught four yea rs in Tennessee and completed her teaching career, retiring after 34 yea rs of service in Kentucky. Bill sought the office of Commonwealth's Attorn ey for Bell County, was elected as a write-in candidate for county surveyo r, and was later elected to serve as 44th Judicial District Court Judg e, a position he held until his retirement 21 years later. To this unio n, at Beverly, was born Mary Truitt Knuckles. Mary Truitt married Charl es Hunter Watley, son of Dr Vernon Thompson Watley and Mary Margaret Moor e, natives of Texas and to this union , in Lexington KY was born Rebekah V erna Watley. The Knuckles family is considered a "founding family" in Be ll County. Marjorie and Bill were considered by those who knew th em to be honest, fair, decent citizens who tried to make a contributi on to their hometown and county. They both loved people and loved to enter tain friends and family in their home, often serving "down-home" country c ooking, including country ham, fried potatoes, fired corn, green beans, gr eens, parsnips, cornbread, iced tea and other traditonal mountain dishe s. Both Marjorie and Bill loved their hometown of Pineville and their ho me county of Bell and were content to live out their lives there. (Submitt ed by Mary Truiit Watley)

[HI12127] (Research):«u»From Memoirs of Uncle Jimmy

«/u»Besides Sally, Mary's eldest child, there were born other children who came with Mary to Little Yellow Creek, now in Bell County, Kentucky, near Middlesboro. The following are the names of the other children who came with Mary into Kentucky: 1) Thomas Jefferson Gabriel, 2) Sol, 3) William Richard, and 4) Louise. Of course, Sally came, too, being the oldest child. After Mary's death on Little Yellow Creek, Sally kept the family together and made a home for them, until a time when Obadiah Knuckles came out of the Tennessee'96Virginia section into the Middlesboro section of Kentucky, and evidently stopped for awhile in the Yellow Creek Valley near Middlesboro. A short time later, Obadiah and his family migrated from the Yellow Creek area to a place on the Stony Fork of the Right Fork of Straight Creek and settled at the mouth of a hollow or branch flowing into Stony Fork Creek. This hollow is still known and named on the Bell County, Kentucky maps as "Knuckles Branch." This Knuckles Branch is located approximately two miles upstream of Stony Fork, a short distance from the late Carter Helton Place. The Mary Robinson Knuckles' Family of at least five children stayed there at the Obadiah Knuckles' new location, now known as Knuckles Branch. Then, Sally and her brothers and sister pulled up and moved on to what is now the upper part or headwaters of Red Bird Creek, this being a part of Clay County. (Bell County was not authorized by the Kentucky General Assembly until 1867.) Sally did some light farming and gardening, and hired out to some of the households of the earlier settlers in the Red Bird Creek area. Sally still kept the family together, especially was I told that the brothers, Gabe (T. J. G.), Sol, and William R. (Bill) lived with her. I don't know whether Sally kept her sister, Louise, or not. I never heard her referred to as being with the family in the Red Bird area. Anyway, it seems that Louise may have lived with others until grown up, since she married a Kirby and lived on Moore's Creek, South of Pineville, or what is now known as Ferndale Community. Moore's Creek flows into Cannon Creek in the Ferndale Community, and this is the area where the Pineville (Bell) Water System Dam on Cannon Creek impounds a large lake on the headwaters of Cannon Creek, and from which Pineville and wide areas of territory up Cumberland River to Fourmile, to Greasy Creek and Straight Creek gets water. So it is not known, or been given to the writer, very much about Louise Knuckles Kirby's early life, or with whom she made her house before she married Kirby. I know the Kirby Family of boys, Jim, Joe, Henry, and sister, Henrietta Kirby Wilson Taylor, called William Richard Knuckles' eight sons "cousins." Henrietta Kirby first married a Wilson, and after his decease, she married Garrett Taylor, a son of Harrison Taylor. Harrison was the son of Cornelius Taylor, and Cornelius was the brother of Patsy Taylor, who married Bobby DePriest, a Revolutionary war soldier, and this Patsy Taylor DePriest was the Grandmother of Lucinda Bingham Asher, Mary DePriest being the Mother of Lucinda Bingham Asher. Lucinda, daughter of Joshua Bingham and Mary DePriest, was the Mother of "Mandy" or Amanda Jane Asher, the wife of William Richard Knuckles, the Mother of my Father, William Letcher Knuckles.

«tab»All of Mary Robinson Knuckles' children bore the name of Knuckles, since she was married to Bill Knuckles, the Father of Sally Knuckles; but it was rumored that "Old Bill" Knuckles was not the father of some of the other members of the family that bore the Knuckles' family name. My Father, Letcher, told me, or I heard him and his brothers speak of the probability of others being the fathers of some of the Knuckles' family members. My Father said that Thomas Jefferson Gabriel (known as "Gabe") was reputed or said to have been a Carroll; Sol, probably a Collins; and, some said that William Richard "Bill" was probably a Helton. Of course, and usually, it happens that a divorced woman who has a large family may be said to have had affairs with many men, but since all these children came out of Tennessee with Mary Robinson and were all born within a short time of each other, it does not stand to reason that Mary could have, or would have, had affairs with so many men, to the extent that such a large family of children would have been born out of wedlock. Anyway, all the children and heirs of Mary grew into adulthood and were good citizens of their respective communities in which they resided.

[NI12130] David M. Burns wrote a book called QUESTS (Washington, D.C: Universal, Inc, 2002), page

48, in which he discussed his meeting with Millard:

"It is obligatory in Bell County and, for that matter, everywhere in Appalachia, when first

meeting someone, to enquire if you and the stranger might be related, and if so, how? That

happened my first day at Red Bird when I wandered into the tiny shack that served as General

Store for the remote settlement. Millard Knuckles owned the store, and within a f ew minutes

determined that we were 'cousins,' presumably through my grandmother, Nancy Knuckles.'

"Cousin or not, that first encounter scared me to death. 'Uncle Millard' kept a Chow-Chow

dog, a somewhat exotic breed today; but positively weird to find one so far back in the woods.

I had been in the store no more than ten minutes before his dog imagined I did some fool thing

that deeply offended his canine sensibilities... and he lunged, biting a sizeable hunk out of my

leg. He would have made it all the way to bone if Uncle Millard hadn't beat him off, all the

while laughing like a hyena at such an enjoyable respite from his humdrum routine. I

continued to patronize the little General Store, and Uncle Millard continued to call me Cousin.

Today I cross the street if I see a Chow coming down the sidewalk."

Ray Helton of Stoney Fork, KY, wrote an article in March 2010 for the "Kentucky Explorer"

magazine about his experiences on Millard's property. He said that the boys attending Red

Bird School would sneak off the campus and go over to Mr. Knuckles' store/post office or to

his large barn across the road. He said they would get out of sight of the school and would

have great times smoking and/or fighting in privacy. Names of participants included Robert

Knuckles, Eugene Brock, Ray Asher, Charles Bruce Knuckles, O'Dell Knuckles, Cody

Knuckles, Winston Asher, Connie Brock, Leonard Asher, Leroy Knuckles, T . J . Brock, Jack B.

Asher, and Ray Knuckles.

Froma Janene Simpson 2014

Millard and Myrtle Kinningham had 3 children: (you can get their info in genealogy book or I'm sure you have it in the Knuckles book): Helen, Lydia and Esther. Helen died of TB (tuberculosis) when she was 17 years, 7 months and 7 days old (or so Mother said). Mother and Helen were like sisters. When Helen became ill, Mother never left her side - even at night! They ate out of the same plate and drank out of the same cup/glass! They had been close all their lives. Mother had no sisters, just brothers to play with, so Helen was like a sister she did not have. The night Helen died my grandparents, Letcher and Carrrie, Mother were down at Uncle Millard and Aunt Myrtle's. Uncle Jimmie had bought a fruit basket to Helen from out in town (Pineville). Helen told Uncle Jimmie that she would eat it in the morning! She passed on to Jesus later that evening. Mother remembered vividly, as they were walking home, through the school, dormitory and church grounds and getting ready to cross the footlog, this little white lamb running so fast that its feet and whole body was up off the ground !!!! She ran faster than ever to get home and when she got in the front screen door, which was never locked, she fainted... I suppose from the traumatic death of her closest friend and 1st cousin, Helen! Mother told me that story and I cried every time I heard it! I don't see why Mother didn't contract TB - she and Helen ate and drank together. She told me they took turns chewing the same gum. Back there, back then, at Red Bird, chewing gum was hard to come by! They shared it! Everyone did! I suppose TB is not contagious all the time.

Dr George Nuckles Dies At His Home

Services Will Be Held Wednesdat Afternoon in Sweeney Chapel

Dr George T Nuckles, 72, an osteopath physician who had practiced in Marsh all since February 1, 1906 passed away at 8:05 o'clock last night in his h ome, 7 East Eastwood. Dr Nuckles had been ill the last ten days. Funeral s ervices will be held at 2 o'clock Wednesday afternoon in the Sweeney Chape l. Rev J Herbert Gilmore, Jr , pastor of the First Baptist Church will off iciate, assisted by Dr harvey Baker Smith, pastor of the Christian Churc h. Interment will be in Ridge Cemetery. The body will remain at the funer al home through the service. Dr Nuckles was born in Bowling Green, MO, N ov 5, 1882, the son of Ella Eugenia Robinson Nuckles of near Bowling Gre en and Richard Nuckles of West Virginia, who moved to marshall in May of 1 892. Dr Nuckles attended Missouri Valley College two years and graduated f rom the American School of Osteopathy, Kirksville, in 1906. He would ha ve completed fifty years of practice in Marshall next February. He was a m ember of the Missouri Osteopathic Assoc, the American Osteopathic Assoc, a nd was a pioneer in the field of osteopathy, always keeping abreast of mod ern developments in medicine. Surviving are his wife, the former Alice M S immons, to whom he was married in 1935, and their son Richard, now a stude nt of Missouri Valley College, both of the home; two children from his pre vious marriage who reside in Kansas City, George T Nuckles Jr and Mrs Char lie (Dorothy) Bauer and three grandchildren; his brother, Dr Robert H Nuck les of Slater, a nephew, Dr R T Nuckles of marshall and a niece, M rs J Ed Taylor of Marshall and a number of great nieces and nephews. He w as preceded in death in 1942 by an infant daughter, Martha Jean.

DAILY DEMOCRAT NEWS HISTORY OF SALINE COUNTY OSTEOPATHS

The Osteopathic Profession, founding and growth, by Dr. C.F. Warren

Osteopathy, as a school of medicine, began when the first class of studen ts was graduated in 1894 after learning new principles and techniques und er Andrew Taylor Still (1828-1917). Still, the founder of Osteopathy, s on of an itinerant Methodist minister and doctor, began his professional l ife as a country doctor with no more or less training than other country d octors of that time.

He supplemented a medical apprenticeship, served with his father, by sever al terms in a medical school at Kansas City. In 1874 when Still sought t he privilege of explaining his ideas at Baldwin University, Kansas, he w as refused because his thoughts were not in conformity with accepted medic al practice of the day. For the next 18 years he continued to study and wo rk alone.

In 1892 Dr. William Smith, who had received his degree in medicine from t he University of Edinburg consulted with Still concerning current medic al education and his own resources regarding the etiology and manageme nt of disease. Two months later Dr. Still, with the assistance of Dr. Smit h, opened a small school for the purpose of teaching anatomy. He subsequen tly established the American School of Osteopathy to teach his ideas relat ive to the etiology and management of disease. A comprehensive curricul um was developed, paralleling good medical education of the day. The cour se covered a period of two years which was, the standard of most medical s chools of that time.

Following the establishment of this first school at Kirksville, Mo, oste o- pathic colleges were rapidly established in other states.
